prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CN+CO+H2CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spectral setup using 3 important lines on disk: H2CO, CN and CO.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The spectral setup covers all important hyperfine components of CN N=2-1, plus the CO J=2-1 transition. In addition, another high resolution band is set on the H2CO 211.211 GHz line, which sometimes happen to be stronger than CN for the younger sources.
The sensitivity goal is set to 7 mJy/beam for 0.2 km/s spectral resolution and the desired angular resolution is around 0.6".
1 band are left in TDM to provide continuum sensitivity. Self-calibration will ultimately be possible on the continuum sources.

High spectral resolution is required to filter the cloud emission, particularly important in rho Oph
Spectral smoothing is applied on the CO and H2CO bands to reduce the data rate, but still match the CN spectral resolution.
Spectroscopy is essential here. Spectral smoothing as been applied on the CO and H2CO bands to reduce the data rate, but still match the CN spectral resolution.

The angular resolution is set to 0.6", in general sufficient to measure rotation curves in disks as demonstrated by previous IRAM experiments.
The largest angular scale is limited to 2-3" because of the Keplerian shear.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CN+CO+CS
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spectral setup using 3 important lines on disk: CN, CS and CO.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The spectral setup covers all important hyperfine components of CN N=2-1, plus the CO J=2-1 transition, and the CS J=5-4 line, which can be a good tracer of turbulence. The sensitivity goal is set to 7 mJy/beam for 0.2 km/s spectral resolution and the desired angular resolution is around 0.6".
1 bands is left in TDM to provide continuum sensitivity. Self-calibration will ultimately be possible on the continuum sources.
The Higher spectral resolution is required to best filter the possible contamination by cloud emission.
Spectroscopy is essential here. Should that cause an unsurmountable obstacle, we could however eventually smooth the CS and CO bands by a factor 2, reducing the rate to close to 12 Mbit/s

The angular resolution is 0.6", sufficient to measure disk masses as illustrated by previous IRAM measurements. The largest angular scale is in general smaller than 2-3", because of the Keplerian shear.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to measure the masses of young (< 10 Myr old) low-mass (< 0.5 solar masses) stars by the rotation of their circumstellar disks. The results will enable astronomers to obtain an improved understanding of the ages of the stars, their mass spectrum, and the evolution of their planet- forming disks. In particular, it will 1) resolve a fundamental discrepancy between spectral type determination made using visible spectra only and other methods, and 2) validate the theoretical tracks, and provide a direct age estimate for stars using the L/M**2 ratio. Note to the TAC: We are resubmitting our approved Cycle 2 project because the array will not be in the configuration we need until after the Cycle 3 deadline. If our project is observed during Cycle 2, we request that this proposal be withdrawn.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
